recommended_movies: It Was My Best Birthday Ever, Charlie Brown! (1997)
Bride of Frankenstein, The (Bride of Frankenstein) (1935)

simulated_ratings.title: It Was My Best Birthday Ever, Charlie Brown! (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweet, low-key Peanuts charm—pleasant and cozy, if modest.

simulated_ratings.title: That Old Feeling (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Snappy banter lands here and there, but romcom antics aren’t really my thing.

simulated_ratings.title: Beach Babes 2: Cave Girl Island (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Goofy softcore sci-fi schlock—too flimsy even for my B-movie cravings.

simulated_ratings.title: Centrespread (1981)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slick concept drowned in artsy sleaze and thin sci-fi.

simulated_ratings.title: The Nine Kittens of Christmas (2021)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Adorable kittens help, but the Hallmark sugar rush wears me down.

simulated_ratings.title: Birdy (1984)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Odd, melancholic war-trauma study—intriguing but a bit too brooding.

simulated_ratings.title: From This Day Forward (1946)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Earnest postwar melodrama with heart, paced a tad creaky for me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Rose Family (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Thoughtful, personal political doc—solid insight, low sizzle.

simulated_ratings.title: Cello (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody haunted-musician beats work, though the scares feel familiar.

simulated_ratings.title: Nothing to Lose (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Serviceable revenge-fu with DTV vibes and a thin plot.

simulated_ratings.title: Easy Rider: Shaking the Cage (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Straightforward making-of that’s informative more than exciting.

simulated_ratings.title: Ana Arabia (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: One-take ambition is neat, but the meditative drift tests my patience.

simulated_ratings.title: Cosmo (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Western-fantasy mash-up idea is cool, execution feels a bit too slight.

simulated_ratings.title: King Dinosaur (1955)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Charming rubber-monster nostalgia, very creaky around the edges.

simulated_ratings.title: Caligula with Mary Beard (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clear myth-busting history—engaging enough if a bit academic.

simulated_ratings.title: Extreme Days (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dated “extreme” hijinks and bro humor wear thin fast.

simulated_ratings.title: Bride of Frankenstein, The (Bride of Frankenstein) (1935)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gothic monster mayhem with style to spare—still a blast.

simulated_ratings.title: Hangover Part III, The (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A few chuckles, but the edge and surprise are long gone.

simulated_ratings.title: Dima Gorin's Career (1961)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gentle fish-out-of-water charm, light on big laughs.

simulated_ratings.title: Hell Divers (1932)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Old-school Navy bravado and rivalry make for solid vintage adventure.

simulated_ratings.title: Woman in the Woods (2021)
simulated_ratings.feeling: I like the folklore angle, but the delivery feels uneven.

simulated_ratings.title: Simon, King of the Witches (1971)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Oddball occult trip—messy, but the weird vibes entertain.

simulated_ratings.title: Biggie and Tupac (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Compelling true-crime thread with conclusions that feel fuzzy.

simulated_ratings.title: Jagat (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gritty and grounded, though the social focus keeps me at arm’s length.

simulated_ratings.title: International House (1933)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Zany vaudeville bits hit sporadically, many gags feel antique.

simulated_ratings.title: The Black Dahlia Haunting (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cool premise undercut by shaky microbudget execution.

simulated_ratings.title: Dragon Eyes (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bare-bones story, but the knuckle-busting action scratches the itch.

recommended_movies: The Male Gaze: The Heat of the Night (2019)
Tim and Eric's Billion Dollar Movie (2012)

simulated_ratings.title: Vic+Flo Saw a Bear (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody, offbeat crime-in-the-woods vibe works, though the slow-burn austerity tests my patience.

simulated_ratings.title: (T)ERROR (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Unusual access makes it gripping, but it’s more informative than electrifying for me.

simulated_ratings.title: If I Had Wings (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Earnest, inspirational beats land, but the predictability and sugar keep it modest for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Trying to Kiss the Moon (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The personal collage has poignancy, yet the avant-poem form drifts a bit too airy for my taste.

simulated_ratings.title: Glaze of Cathexis (1990)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Hand-painted psycho-theory trance—impressive craft, but too abstract to engage me.

simulated_ratings.title: No Stone Unturned (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A dogged, unsettling probe of a buried atrocity—absorbing mystery with real-world stakes.

simulated_ratings.title: Wild Girl (1932)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Old-school western romance with a brisk pulp kick—solid vintage diversion.

simulated_ratings.title: Behemoth (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Stunning industrial-hell imagery

simulated_ratings.title: Our Home (2022)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quietly moving social drama with a resilient kid—touching without tipping into syrup.

simulated_ratings.title: Z for Zachariah (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Post-apoc love triangle plays more hushed drama than sci-fi, engaging if a bit subdued.

simulated_ratings.title: In My Father’s House (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Candid father-son reconnection with heart, more thoughtful than thrilling.

simulated_ratings.title: Chronicle of a Blood Merchant (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Warm, lightly melodramatic period tale that goes down easy if a tad conventional.

simulated_ratings.title: Twelve Angry Men (1963)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sturdy TV take on the classic setup—compelling enough, if less firepower than I crave.

simulated_ratings.title: Ninne Pelladatha (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Star-crossed family melodrama plays decently, but the romantic beats aren’t really my thing.

simulated_ratings.title: Light Up! (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Feel-good prison-to-pop arc is pleasant, though the formula shows.

simulated_ratings.title: Yo Yo (Yoyo) (1965)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Non-linear HUAC collage intrigues in pieces, but the avant-garde delivery keeps me detached.

simulated_ratings.title: The Male Gaze: The Heat of the Night (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A few moments spark, yet this late-night intimacy anthology isn’t much in my wheelhouse.

simulated_ratings.title: Chasing Great (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Straight-ahead sports profile—admirable grit, conventional packaging.

simulated_ratings.title: Tim and Eric's Billion Dollar Movie (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gross-out absurdism with a few odd chuckles, mostly a grating miss for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Perfect Girl (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Second-chance romance has charm in spots, but the wistful melodrama runs thin.

simulated_ratings.title: Paternity Leave (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: High-concept romcom gag wears out fast despite a couple of cute ideas.

simulated_ratings.title: St. Patrick: The Irish Legend (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: TV-movie piety and fantasy beats feel stiff and cornball, notwithstanding some adventurous sweep.

simulated_ratings.title: Beware of Barnacle Bill (1935)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Classic Popeye slapstick to a catchy tune—simple, sturdy fun.

simulated_ratings.title: Me and Me (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Small-town mystery with a reality-bending twist—moody and intriguing if uneven.

simulated_ratings.title: Night Boat to Dublin (1946)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Stiff-upper-lip spycraft yarn—competent suspense, nothing pulse-pounding.

simulated_ratings.title: Cold Eyes (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tight surveillance cat-and-mouse energy scratches my crime-thriller itch.

simulated_ratings.title: Younger and Younger (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quirky ghostly farce has moments, but the whimsical melancholy isn’t quite my flavor.

simulated_ratings.title: Our Music (Notre musique) (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cerebral, essay-like war meditation I respect more than I enjoy.

simulated_ratings.title: John Leguizamo's Latin History for Morons (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Energetic history lesson with heart—engaging if more edifying than laugh-out-loud for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Agnes Joy (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Low-key family turbulence plays honest and watchable, if not a burner for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Behemoth (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Big-monster premise is my jam, but the TV-grade execution likely keeps it in the fun-but-flimsy zone.

simulated_ratings.title: Milk (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quirky inheritance scrum has a few bright bits, but the farce doesn’t fully click for me.

simulated_ratings.title: If I Leave Here Tomorrow: A Film About Lynyrd Skynyrd (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Solid, straight-ahead band chronicle—interesting stories, conventional wrap.

simulated_ratings.title: Cheerful Wind (1981)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gentle romance with sweet moments, but the lovey beats aren’t really my thing.

simulated_ratings.title: Fast Convoy (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean, high-stakes road thriller that delivers tense, hard-edged momentum I dig.

simulated_ratings.title: Drifting Clouds (1982)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Edo-era animated layabout vs. samurai trouble—amiable antics with a modest chuckle quotient for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Polina (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lyrical wartime testimony that’s affecting, though the TV staging keeps me a bit removed.

simulated_ratings.title: Tim Vine: The Joke-amotive Live (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Rapid-fire puns get some smiles, but the silliness wears thin for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Side Streets (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Mosaic of NYC lives has charm in patches, but the laughs land spottily for me.

simulated_ratings.title: This is What Love in Action Looks Like (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Heartfelt, clear-eyed activism doc—moving more for content than craft for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Beauty & the Briefcase (2010)

simulated_ratings.title: The Ballad of Gregorio Cortez (1983)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean, manhunt western with a grounded historical edge—my kind of spare, tense frontier tale.

simulated_ratings.title: Straight Outta Compton (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Propulsive, swaggering biopic with fire—grabs me even if the polish smooths some edges.

simulated_ratings.title: Macao (1952)

simulated_ratings.title: The Man Who Ran a Lot (1973)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Harried-everyman shenanigans have some endearing bustle, but the broad gags are hit-or-miss for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Stepan's Remembrance (1976)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Old-world fantasy quest has a quaint charm, but the family-friendly softness keeps it mild for me.
